Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Reproductive Fitness and Sharing in Cooperative Societies
Award.AbstractNarration: The mating system of the acorn woodpecker (Melanerpes formicivorus) is among the most complex of any vertebrate: groups consist of up to seven breeding males, as many as three reproductive females and a variable number helpers (offspring of previous years that remain on the natal territory and do not breed). Males compete to mate and females lay their eggs communally in the same nest. Breeders of the same sex are almost always close relatives, either siblings or parents and offspring. Previous work showed that joint-nesting groups of females, unlike males, share parentage equally. This project will determine the factors that influence reproductive sharing in acorn woodpecker societies by combining fieldwork on color-marked birds with modern molecular techniques to identify individuals that successfully produce young within social groups and to quantify their behavior. A primary goal of the project is to understand the fitness consequences of cooperative breeding and to integrate findings into the larger questions of the evolution and ecology of group living in highly social species, including humans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Acorn woodpecker (Melanerpes formicivorus) societies are complex, which has always made them challenging, but provides unique opportunities that are unavailable in most species. The data we collected allowed us to test hypotheses concerning delayed dispersal, helping behavior, and coalition formation by both male and female relatives. We addressed evolutionary interesting behaviors and linked them to ecological factors, largely due to the strong dependence of these birds on stored acorns. Specifically, the parentage data we collected allowed us to tie together the long-term behavioral studies that have formed the foundation of the project for 40 years. Funding for this project allowed us to critically evaluate the limits of kin selection theory and fitness measures for predicting social behavior in complex vertebrate societies.

Acorn woodpeckers are a keystone species within California oak woodlands, a habitat threatened due to urban development, poor regeneration, and “sudden oak death”. These oak woodlands include some of the most extensive old-growth forests remaining in North America (and are part of the California Floristic Province, a “biodiversity hotspot” containing a disproportionate share of endemic and threatened species). The work we completed has been particularly instructive with respect to understanding the role of cavity limitation for a species that is a critical member of the California oak woodland “nest-web”.

The project included a significant educational component in the form of research training of undergraduate students in molecular biology at Gonzaga University (10 participated extensively; 16 others did short-term projects). Most of the 10 students that participated extensively also participated in the research option program available via the Gonzaga Science Education Program with additional funding from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute (HHMI). This project aligns with two of the HHMI goals of recruiting talented science majors into the education field and increasing undergraduate research opportunities, especially for students interested in pursuing careers in science research. Participation in research has significantly helped to prepare these students for the workforce or to continue in graduate programs and educational programs in the sciences. For example, students who participated in the project have matriculated into medical school and dental school, and another is currently teaching science to 8th graders for Teach for America.
